channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference 2025
item.description: Greenville, South Carolina, USA
item.dc:subject: Events

item.title: Follow me on LinkedIn
item.description: If you use LinkedIn I'd like to invite you to follow me on that platform or if you like, send me a connect request. In that case, please include a note that you are are reader of the Perl Weekly newsletter.
item.dc:subject: The corner of Gabor

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.
item.dc:subject: Weekly collections

item.title: Object Oriented Programming - OOP in Perl
item.description: The first page of my new OOP booklet.
item.dc:subject: Perl Tutorial

item.title: The weekly challenge 326
item.description: Solutions are notable for their clarity and efficiency, demonstrating a deep understanding of Python's capabilities. Exploration of both standard library functions and mathematical approaches provides valuable insights for Python enthusiasts.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #326
item.description: The solution efficiently handles the decompression task using Perl's list manipulation features. Solutions are concise and demonstrate effective use of Perl's modules and list handling capabilities.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Raku Weekly Challenge : Week 326
item.description: The solutions demonstrate Raku's expressive syntax and powerful built-in methods, leading to clean and efficient code. The inclusion of input validation and user-friendly comments further enhances the quality of the solutions.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Weekly Challenge 326
item.description: It emphasizes the importance of using built-in functions for tasks like calculating the day of the year to avoid errors and simplify code. The solutions in both Python and Perl demonstrate clear and efficient approaches to the challenges.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Day of the Decompression
item.description: Provides a comparative analysis of how different programming languages approach the same problems, highlighting the diversity in language features and libraries. The post serves as an insightful resource for programmers interested in exploring multiple solutions to common problems across various languages.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #326
item.description: The solutions are complete and well-documented, providing clear explanations of the logic behind each step. It serves as an excellent resource for Perl programmers looking to improve their problem-solving skills and coding practices.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Days to decompress
item.description: Clear demonstration of using CPAN modules to solve common problems. Concise, readable code snippets.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Got a date with compression!
item.description: Emphasizes the use of core Perl modules (Time::Piece) to avoid reinventing date logic. Mentions best practices such as handling context carefully in the decompression task.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Modern Perl's Victory
item.description: Concise and idiomatic Perl. Code is well structured and leverage robust date/time modules to avoid reinventing calendar logic.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 326
item.description: Solutions are characterized by their simplicity and effective use of Perl's features. The clear explanations and well-structured code make the blog post a valuable resource for Perl enthusiasts.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Happy Birthday Ma’!
item.description: The post not only provides solutions in various programming languages and database systems but also emphasizes the importance of maintaining coding skills and learning new technologies. It showcase the versatility of different languages and tools in solving the same problem, providing valuable insights for developers interested in exploring multiple programming environments.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Length of a Day
item.description: PDL offers elegant ways to handle list transformations via vectorized operations. The post illustrates a concise and advanced Perl style that values reuse and idiomatic tools.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 326
item.description: The post is well-written and shows how Raku and Perl handle the same problem with slight idiomatic differences.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Decompressed Day
item.description: Solutions are succinct, leveraging Raku's expressive standard library. Emphasizes type and input validation in the signature, promoting reliability.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: TWC326
item.description: The solutions are clear, concise, and make good use of Perl's standard modules and operators. The second task uses manual iteration, which is easy to follow and avoids recursion or map-heavy constructs.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Day We Decompress
item.description: Well-commented, educational, and test-driven structure. Offers neat and idiomatic Perl solutions that avoid overengineering.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 326
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Day of the Year" and "Decompressed List" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 327
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Missing Integers" and "MAD". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Array vs List
item.description: Find out the subtle difference between Array and List in Perl.

item.title: Analysing FIT data with Perl: interactive data analysis
item.description: For more fine-grained analysis of FIT file data, it’d be great to be able to investigate it interactively.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Upcoming Dancer2 2.0.0 release
item.description: The Dancer Core Team is excitedly preparing a major release of Dancer2, 2.0.0. In advance of this, I'd like to give you all a preview of what to expect.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: OOP in Perl, Functional programming in Python, CLI in Rust
item.description: I have been teaching Perl for 25 years (and Python and Rust for a shorter period of time). Most of my courses were geared towards corporations and they are 3-4-5 days long, 8 hours a day covering a lot of subjects. Today it seems we need very short and very focused courses. So I am splitting my long courses into subject and will run those mini-courses. The first 3 I've announced are about Object Oriented Programming in Perl, Functional Programming in Python, and Creating a command line tool in Rust. Check out if any of these courses would be interesting to you or to some of your co-workers! If you have any question, send me an email (szabgab@gmail.com) or contact me via LinkedIn or join our Telegram channel.
item.dc:subject: Sponsors

item.title: #726 - Perl and ChatGPT
item.description:
Hi there,

Most of us have explored and seen the power of ChatGPT. Last week, Dave Cross shared very interesting tool written in Perl to create podcast for the Perl Weekly newsletter. We already have podcast for Week #723, Week #724 and Week #725. I am very impressed with the content and sound quality. Great job, Dave. You can checkout the code in the GitHub repository.

Another post, Slice of Perl by Dave Cross inspired me to write about Array vs List in Perl.

For all Dancer2 fan, we have a good news, very soon there would be Dancer2 2.0.0 release. I am very excited and looking forward to it.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: Editorial
